Total War: Rome II is a rich and engaging strategy game that blends empire management with large scale real-time battles. The campaign offers meaningful choices, whether you focus on diplomacy, economy, or military conquest, and each faction has its own unique strengths and playstyle. Battles are epic, with thousands of units fighting on detailed and immersive battlefields. The visuals, sound design, and historical atmosphere create a convincing and enjoyable experience. Overall, Rome II is a must play for anyone who loves deep strategy and ancient history.

I guess there were some serious issues at launch but Rome II - EE is a pretty great TW game. There are issues with the game becoming a major slog mid-late game, once you've pretty much dominated your neighbors, but the combat is fun and the graphics look good. Some people don't like how resources are now managed at the province level, and you can no longer build every little town into a rival of Roma, but really, it's a non issue once you get the hang of managing food and learning what to build and where.

Also worth noting that the Workshop has tons of mods, from minor music enhancements, to complete overhauls. which extends the replayability of the game once you get done with the included scenarios (which are good, especially teutoburg forest).

Rome II is peak Total War. The mix of huge battles, empire building and classic Roman chaos still hits perfectly even now.

The game handles Roman history in a way that feels genuinely fun. The Marian Reforms shake up your armies, politics is always stirring trouble and the civil war hangs over the campaign like a storm you know is coming. For a video game, it handles units and historical shifts with surprising accuracy. Each faction feels distinct and the major moments of Roman history actually matter in gameplay.

Battles feel massive and watching a Roman line hold under pressure never gets old. The campaign map is still one of the strongest in the series and it is dangerously easy to fall into the “one more turn” loop.

When this game was announced in 2012, me and my friends were stoked. We sat on the school bus talking about how incredible it looked and how our PCs were probably not going to run it. Now it is 2025, I get home from work and I stick the settings on extreme quality, still enjoy diving into a custom battle or starting a fresh campaign. The magic has not worn off.

Playing Rome II again only highlights how strong this era of Total War was. We need a return to this level of ambition, depth and overall quality.

Rome II is like SimCity (2013), a mediocre game that tries every single way to piss you off. The difference between them is that SimCity had their reckoning, which came from Cities Skylines, & after the reckoning, no one cared about SimCity (2013) except as a weird gimmick from the past. However, Rome II has never had true competition, & as such, people had to make do by modding it. Some of those mods that came out make this game great; however, the base game that you paid for remains mediocre to this day. You don't pay for the game; you pay for the game engine that you run someone else's game on. You should also never buy Rome II at AUD $89.9 when you can wait a month & get it for AUD $22.5, which, even at that price, is still taking the piss out of you from this old game. The DLC pricing for this game is on such a level that even EA would start taking notes. It's okay to like these two games, but people recognise that SimCity (2013) was bad. I do believe that most people here who are saying that this is a great game have some form of Stockholm syndrome. Rome II is bad; it never got good, nor was it replaced by something superior, & it's unworthy of being the best grand battle game set in Roman times.

Probably the most annoying Total War game. 

From sloppy, unsatisfying battles that are more stat mashing than tactics, to an unintuitive political system that would be better off not existing, to a kneecapped campaign map with limited armies, to a frustrating province system that is more spreadsheet and encyclopedia book than strategic.

While far from a terrible game, any one of the above issues alone make this game pale in comparison to any of the previous titles, including the original Rome Total War. Any time I get the Total War itch and attempt to gain enjoyment from this game and uncover the mystery of why it is well received, and now over a decade old and still one of the most played Total War games, the first battle is a crushing reminder of how tepidly middling, frustrating and unsatisfying this game is. 

For every fault this game has, a previous title corrects(I say that as someone who got into Total War with this game!), and for every new feature this game adds with merit, Attila does better. Rome 2 Total War isn’t awful, but I absolutely hate this game with every fibre of my being, and I think less of you for enjoying it. 

To give some examples of how this game plays out on the battle and campaign map;

BATTLES:

I fought off an attacking army with a garrison, killing the enemy general. The garrison is of predetermined composition that cannot be supplemented without sacrificing a limited field army slot. The next turn the same enemy army attacks my same settlement, and while both my garrison and the enemy army are depleted. However,  because I made the strategic error of killing the enemy general in the last engagement(Sun Zu warns about this!), this enemy army has a completely new and fully replenished elite general’s unit in this battle. Despite completely surrounding this general, my skirmishers emptying into its exposed flanks, this elite unit easily overcomes and destroys my weakened garrison. Where’s the strategy in this? I was actively punished for winning a battle by the fact that the enemy, in my territory, can replenish an entire unit powerful enough to single handedly win battles. My garrison, being limited to the defence of the settlement, is forced to just watch this defeated army sit outside the gates and magically create a new elite generals body guard that will soon slaughter them all!

I made the mistake of playing a Sparta campaign as one of my first campaigns. Sparta is perhaps the faction that makes this game's issues the most apparent, as its roster consists of units with high defence and low killing power, and limited cavalry. Most battles were reduced to slugging matches where after my skirmishers depleted their ammunition, I could do nothing but click 3x speed and watch my superior stats grind down the enemies. Unlike previous games, battles rely far less on morale and it is much more likely units will fight until 10-15 men remain. While this does draw out battles in a way that in theory could introduce more tactical options, in reality it just means you have time to micro your cavalry and skirmishers twice as much to squeeze out a few more kills.

It should be noted that the new health pool units have make skirmishers busted and cavalry pathetic. Instead of a dice roll if an arrow kills or glances a model, it deals damage that slowly whittles down a unit. Meanwhile a cavalry charge now works in that same fashion, so a charge that would decimate a unit in the original Rome total war might in this game deal damage without killing a single model!  

CAMPAIGN MAP

The province system limits building options, reducing choice and strategic depth into a spreadsheet meta builder. Where as in the first game, you might have to consider the costs and time of building roads to connect your elite barracks in your home region to your frontier, or perhaps setting up a new recruitment center closer to the front, or maybe a region is overpopulated to the point of squalor and needs more governance. In this game these choices are practically predetermined. Provinces must be specialized into either economic or military with limited building slots at your disposal. Public order is an active consideration that needs to be balanced constantly. It gives the illusion of choice with 15 different types of each cultural, economic and public order building trees, but in reality this just leads to a moment of frustrating confusion as you figure out the ideal building layout for each province through the cumbersome encyclopedia. There isn't a strategy to decide which of the 15 different economic buildings offers a 5% bonus to income, or which of 15 different public order buildings I need to most efficiently keep the province stable. It is an incredibly cumbersome and mind numbing task. 

You’ll also have to stake out a single province to place down all the military buildings and their minor stat boosting compatriots. It's hilarious how poorly implemented and thought out the military building is. To field the whole roster you’ll need a whole province dedicated to the task, leaving most of your units to the mid game when you have etched out enough space. The AI doesn’t have this ability, so most factions spend the entire game with one region and one stack of tier one spear units, the only units they can recruit. I can’t stress out enough just how bad this is, why would I invest in one or two military buildings spread out and unbalancing the awful public order/economy mini game, when I might as well wait out a few more turns with tier one slop and mercenaries until I can plop down each kind of barracks and each kind of stat boosting military building in one province? It is just absolutely mind-boggeling the game is designed this way, both for the player and the fact the AI is totally incapable of interacting with it in a meaningful way! 

The politics system is something I can only imagine no player wants to deal with. In theory it offers interesting mechanics and organic fleshed out civil wars, in reality it is just a nerf to expansion and a chore to deal with. Every couple of turns you have to check in on it, click a few buttons out of dozens of confusing options to bring everything back to stasis. 

I could go into the deep reaching effects the removal of general-less armies has, but this review is long enough!

I thought that the version I played long time ago was kinda an early release and the issues are resolved but this game has too many major problems that it's hard to list them all (steam review limitations). I do my best to list them as much as I can with evidence and comparison to rome 1.
- The archery in this game is so bad that slingers have more range and power than any archer in the game. In rome 1, slingers have short range and they shoot straight instead of a ballistic trajectory. Projectiles in rome 2 have a very lame slow motion trajectories to the point that you can easily dodge them. Also your unit flashes red before it's hit by enemy arrow even just before the enemy shoots its arrows. Also in rome 1, height advantage was immediate, to the point that even slightest change of elevation would change the range of your archers in a certain direction. Rome 2 is more like a simplistic mobile game that your units have a fixed circle of range around them.
- The game has insane friendly fire similar to rome 1. However, rome 1 barbaric invasion fixed this issue to a great degree. In this game one single enemy horse gets too close to your archers and instead of fleeing when facing 10000 archers, it jumps in and your archers just kill each other by shooting 1000 arrows into each other.
- Enemy AI is way worse than rome 1. The enemy just follows you even when they make a fort to defend themselves. In rome 1, this behavior could be seen only when the enemy had significantly larger army to just blindly chase you. The enemy archers tactically flee even when they are behind a massive army. So you can easily trick them to stop shooting by spam attack and cancel. This behavior existed in rome 1 to a limited degree but the AI was smart enough to camp behind the line and continuously shoot.
- There are near zero physics in this game, much less than rome 1. For instance, in rome 1, shield was a real object that the direction of arrow and shield would matter a lot. This game is pretty much a mobile game such that the arrows just hit sponges and usually they kill no matter how large the shield is or the direction of the shield. It doesn't matter if you shoot enemy from behind or front, they just carry shield on their head and things are pretty much like Age of Empires 1.
- The campaign AI is so annoying. Enemies just go to force march and dodge your entire army and when you force march to chase, on next turn they cancel force march and ambush you and destroy all your army while ally armies can't join because it's an "ambush" then they again switch to force march and disappear to the darkness of the map. The only way to counter is to just hide in cities or chase enemy army by normal marching like idiots and AI just runs around for 1000 turns and if you forget to do your move for one turn you lose your entire army and city.
- The enemy decides to take siege of your city and you immediately lose soldiers due to starvation!
- Attacking a city has too many bugs. Battering rams not attacking gates (cursor doesn't change at all), ladders go crazy. I thought that these were bugs that were fixed in later versions but it seems like these bugs are some features of the game.
- The stupid mobile game "policies" and penalties of "expansionism" is so bad to the point that when you start the game, you ask yourself "why should I fight?". You can just make a few same-culture allies and sit there forever and your allies take the entire earth. No penalty no gameplay.
- In this game, there is limited charge implementation. Units are kinda spongy and they just rub into each other. In rome 1, even if you had the worst cavalry with a bow and near zero melee ability, you could order to charge and they charged properly even if they die immediately on contact. In rome 2, your soldiers are just confused and just walk to enemy then turn around in a confused way. Even foot soldiers had proper charge in rome 1, even the peasants. In rome 2, they pretend to charge but almost no action is happening.
- In rome 1, there was a tiny chance that a soldier gets confused in city and gets lost far away from its unit usually when a gate is too crowded. Rome 2 doesn't have tight streets, rocky terrain, and dense buildings but soldier fragmentation happens a lot! The worst part is that if enemy attacks that single soldier far away from the unit, your entire unit 1 mile away would say "we are attacked from behind" and flees! In rome 1, if a soldier is lost and bumps into enemy, the unit 1 mile away won't flee for being attacked from behind or something.
- In rome 1, you could not send 10 soldiers to attack 500 enemy soldiers even if you have 10000 soldiers on the battlefield far away. In rome 2, you always need to kill enemy unit to the last soldier even if it is completely isolated. The morale system is very simplistic so that soldiers only care about total size of armies and barely care about their situation. Even mobs rarely flee early and you have to kill almost to the last soldier. I hate how simplistic and stupid the morale system is. Losing generals has very small effect in rome 2. In rome 1, death of a fancy general caused a massive morale loss of your army and when the general was alive, even if he was far away, the effect on total morale was big. Also, I never ever seen enemy army deciding to flee early based on the situation in rome 2. In rome 1, sometimes the enemy was deciding to entirely flee from the battlefield and avoid any contact. In rome 1, a routing unit could change its mind and return to battle but not in rome 2.
- This game has some magical abilities so that you can cast spell on your soldiers and enemy soldiers in a very strange and stupid way. In rome 1, the effect of general was very global and rally barely had any magical effect.
- Fatigue in rome 1 was very sensitive to terrain slope. I don't even notice anything in rome 2. Does this logic even exist? In rome 1, being on a hill not only gave so much power to your archers but also it could make enemy soldiers tired to climb and when they reach to you, they are already tired depending on the slope they had to travel.
- The campaign map has annoying elevation changes and clouds and "unassigned skill" or "unassigned edict" that make the game annoying. The map of rome 1 was easier to understand despite the potential to have many number of armies. In rome 2, you have few armies but the map is hard to understand and flags are less descriptive. Also some factions have very bad color on battlefield that you can't see the type of the unit.
- Why most of the cities don't have even basic walls? I don't like the province system that you control a village and your ally controls the main city. Rome 1 was way better.
- For some reason greeks and romans speak fluent british english while british people in this game kinda talk like pigs snoring and they have worse accent. Historically those greeks and romans were speaking just like these mexicans that high-likely the developers of this game mock them every day. Also asian people have strange offensive dialog that shows some level of propaganda is embedded in this game. Rome 1 had integrity.  Eastern factions constantly say "what cruelty do you wish oh lord?", hmm?
- The music is horrible to the point that violin sound really causes headache in the battles. Compared to rome 1 music, this is absolute garbage that I can't even defend a single battle track of rome 2.

Rome II is like SimCity (2013), a mediocre game that tries every single way to piss you off. The difference between them is that SimCity had their reckoning, which came from Cities Skylines, & after the reckoning, no one cared about SimCity (2013) except as a weird gimmick from the past. However, Rome II has never had true competition, & as such, people had to make do by modding it. Some of those mods that came out make this game great; however, the base game that you paid for remains mediocre to this day. You don't pay for the game; you pay for the game engine that you run someone else's game on. You should also never buy Rome II at AUD $89.9 when you can wait a month & get it for AUD $22.5, which, even at that price, is still taking the piss out of you from this old game. The DLC pricing for this game is on such a level that even EA would start taking notes. It's okay to like these two games, but people recognise that SimCity (2013) was bad. I do believe that most people here who are saying that this is a great game have some form of Stockholm syndrome. Rome II is bad; it never got good, nor was it replaced by something superior, & it's unworthy of being the best grand battle game set in Roman times.

Probably the most annoying Total War game. 

From sloppy, unsatisfying battles that are more stat mashing than tactics, to an unintuitive political system that would be better off not existing, to a kneecapped campaign map with limited armies, to a frustrating province system that is more spreadsheet and encyclopedia book than strategic.

While far from a terrible game, any one of the above issues alone make this game pale in comparison to any of the previous titles, including the original Rome Total War. Any time I get the Total War itch and attempt to gain enjoyment from this game and uncover the mystery of why it is well received, and now over a decade old and still one of the most played Total War games, the first battle is a crushing reminder of how tepidly middling, frustrating and unsatisfying this game is. 

For every fault this game has, a previous title corrects(I say that as someone who got into Total War with this game!), and for every new feature this game adds with merit, Attila does better. Rome 2 Total War isn’t awful, but I absolutely hate this game with every fibre of my being, and I think less of you for enjoying it. 

To give some examples of how this game plays out on the battle and campaign map;

BATTLES:

I fought off an attacking army with a garrison, killing the enemy general. The garrison is of predetermined composition that cannot be supplemented without sacrificing a limited field army slot. The next turn the same enemy army attacks my same settlement, and while both my garrison and the enemy army are depleted. However,  because I made the strategic error of killing the enemy general in the last engagement(Sun Zu warns about this!), this enemy army has a completely new and fully replenished elite general’s unit in this battle. Despite completely surrounding this general, my skirmishers emptying into its exposed flanks, this elite unit easily overcomes and destroys my weakened garrison. Where’s the strategy in this? I was actively punished for winning a battle by the fact that the enemy, in my territory, can replenish an entire unit powerful enough to single handedly win battles. My garrison, being limited to the defence of the settlement, is forced to just watch this defeated army sit outside the gates and magically create a new elite generals body guard that will soon slaughter them all!

I made the mistake of playing a Sparta campaign as one of my first campaigns. Sparta is perhaps the faction that makes this game's issues the most apparent, as its roster consists of units with high defence and low killing power, and limited cavalry. Most battles were reduced to slugging matches where after my skirmishers depleted their ammunition, I could do nothing but click 3x speed and watch my superior stats grind down the enemies. Unlike previous games, battles rely far less on morale and it is much more likely units will fight until 10-15 men remain. While this does draw out battles in a way that in theory could introduce more tactical options, in reality it just means you have time to micro your cavalry and skirmishers twice as much to squeeze out a few more kills.

It should be noted that the new health pool units have make skirmishers busted and cavalry pathetic. Instead of a dice roll if an arrow kills or glances a model, it deals damage that slowly whittles down a unit. Meanwhile a cavalry charge now works in that same fashion, so a charge that would decimate a unit in the original Rome total war might in this game deal damage without killing a single model!  

CAMPAIGN MAP

The province system limits building options, reducing choice and strategic depth into a spreadsheet meta builder. Where as in the first game, you might have to consider the costs and time of building roads to connect your elite barracks in your home region to your frontier, or perhaps setting up a new recruitment center closer to the front, or maybe a region is overpopulated to the point of squalor and needs more governance. In this game these choices are practically predetermined. Provinces must be specialized into either economic or military with limited building slots at your disposal. Public order is an active consideration that needs to be balanced constantly. It gives the illusion of choice with 15 different types of each cultural, economic and public order building trees, but in reality this just leads to a moment of frustrating confusion as you figure out the ideal building layout for each province through the cumbersome encyclopedia. There isn't a strategy to decide which of the 15 different economic buildings offers a 5% bonus to income, or which of 15 different public order buildings I need to most efficiently keep the province stable. It is an incredibly cumbersome and mind numbing task. 

You’ll also have to stake out a single province to place down all the military buildings and their minor stat boosting compatriots. It's hilarious how poorly implemented and thought out the military building is. To field the whole roster you’ll need a whole province dedicated to the task, leaving most of your units to the mid game when you have etched out enough space. The AI doesn’t have this ability, so most factions spend the entire game with one region and one stack of tier one spear units, the only units they can recruit. I can’t stress out enough just how bad this is, why would I invest in one or two military buildings spread out and unbalancing the awful public order/economy mini game, when I might as well wait out a few more turns with tier one slop and mercenaries until I can plop down each kind of barracks and each kind of stat boosting military building in one province? It is just absolutely mind-boggeling the game is designed this way, both for the player and the fact the AI is totally incapable of interacting with it in a meaningful way! 

The politics system is something I can only imagine no player wants to deal with. In theory it offers interesting mechanics and organic fleshed out civil wars, in reality it is just a nerf to expansion and a chore to deal with. Every couple of turns you have to check in on it, click a few buttons out of dozens of confusing options to bring everything back to stasis. 

I could go into the deep reaching effects the removal of general-less armies has, but this review is long enough!

Sucks to say since I loved the first Rome Total War game, but this is genuinely the worst installation in the franchise I've experienced. I won't go into specific critiques because it's honeslty the smallest complaints but they cause constant friction and pile up, but just a few are things like the wonky camera controls, units defaulting to walking over sprinting, slow early game progression, the AI making decisions that are dog-water in their longterm but a masterclass in making your experience miserable. Rome II is like SimCity (2013), a mediocre game that tries every single way to piss you off. The difference between them is that SimCity had their reckoning, which came from Cities Skylines, & after the reckoning, no one cared about SimCity (2013) except as a weird gimmick from the past. However, Rome II has never had true competition, & as such, people had to make do by modding it. Some of those mods that came out make this game great; however, the base game that you paid for remains mediocre to this day. You don't pay for the game; you pay for the game engine that you run someone else's game on. You should also never buy Rome II at AUD $89.9 when you can wait a month & get it for AUD $22.5, which, even at that price, is still taking the piss out of you from this old game. The DLC pricing for this game is on such a level that even EA would start taking notes. It's okay to like these two games, but people recognise that SimCity (2013) was bad. I do believe that most people here who are saying that this is a great game have some form of Stockholm syndrome. Rome II is bad; it never got good, nor was it replaced by something superior, & it's unworthy of being the best grand battle game set in Roman times.

Probably the most annoying Total War game. 

From sloppy, unsatisfying battles that are more stat mashing than tactics, to an unintuitive political system that would be better off not existing, to a kneecapped campaign map with limited armies, to a frustrating province system that is more spreadsheet and encyclopedia book than strategic.

While far from a terrible game, any one of the above issues alone make this game pale in comparison to any of the previous titles, including the original Rome Total War. Any time I get the Total War itch and attempt to gain enjoyment from this game and uncover the mystery of why it is well received, and now over a decade old and still one of the most played Total War games, the first battle is a crushing reminder of how tepidly middling, frustrating and unsatisfying this game is. 

For every fault this game has, a previous title corrects(I say that as someone who got into Total War with this game!), and for every new feature this game adds with merit, Attila does better. Rome 2 Total War isn’t awful, but I absolutely hate this game with every fibre of my being, and I think less of you for enjoying it. 

To give some examples of how this game plays out on the battle and campaign map;

BATTLES:

I fought off an attacking army with a garrison, killing the enemy general. The garrison is of predetermined composition that cannot be supplemented without sacrificing a limited field army slot. The next turn the same enemy army attacks my same settlement, and while both my garrison and the enemy army are depleted. However,  because I made the strategic error of killing the enemy general in the last engagement(Sun Zu warns about this!), this enemy army has a completely new and fully replenished elite general’s unit in this battle. Despite completely surrounding this general, my skirmishers emptying into its exposed flanks, this elite unit easily overcomes and destroys my weakened garrison. Where’s the strategy in this? I was actively punished for winning a battle by the fact that the enemy, in my territory, can replenish an entire unit powerful enough to single handedly win battles. My garrison, being limited to the defence of the settlement, is forced to just watch this defeated army sit outside the gates and magically create a new elite generals body guard that will soon slaughter them all!

I made the mistake of playing a Sparta campaign as one of my first campaigns. Sparta is perhaps the faction that makes this game's issues the most apparent, as its roster consists of units with high defence and low killing power, and limited cavalry. Most battles were reduced to slugging matches where after my skirmishers depleted their ammunition, I could do nothing but click 3x speed and watch my superior stats grind down the enemies. Unlike previous games, battles rely far less on morale and it is much more likely units will fight until 10-15 men remain. While this does draw out battles in a way that in theory could introduce more tactical options, in reality it just means you have time to micro your cavalry and skirmishers twice as much to squeeze out a few more kills.

It should be noted that the new health pool units have make skirmishers busted and cavalry pathetic. Instead of a dice roll if an arrow kills or glances a model, it deals damage that slowly whittles down a unit. Meanwhile a cavalry charge now works in that same fashion, so a charge that would decimate a unit in the original Rome total war might in this game deal damage without killing a single model!  

CAMPAIGN MAP

The province system limits building options, reducing choice and strategic depth into a spreadsheet meta builder. Where as in the first game, you might have to consider the costs and time of building roads to connect your elite barracks in your home region to your frontier, or perhaps setting up a new recruitment center closer to the front, or maybe a region is overpopulated to the point of squalor and needs more governance. In this game these choices are practically predetermined. Provinces must be specialized into either economic or military with limited building slots at your disposal. Public order is an active consideration that needs to be balanced constantly. It gives the illusion of choice with 15 different types of each cultural, economic and public order building trees, but in reality this just leads to a moment of frustrating confusion as you figure out the ideal building layout for each province through the cumbersome encyclopedia. There isn't a strategy to decide which of the 15 different economic buildings offers a 5% bonus to income, or which of 15 different public order buildings I need to most efficiently keep the province stable. It is an incredibly cumbersome and mind numbing task. 

You’ll also have to stake out a single province to place down all the military buildings and their minor stat boosting compatriots. It's hilarious how poorly implemented and thought out the military building is. To field the whole roster you’ll need a whole province dedicated to the task, leaving most of your units to the mid game when you have etched out enough space. The AI doesn’t have this ability, so most factions spend the entire game with one region and one stack of tier one spear units, the only units they can recruit. I can’t stress out enough just how bad this is, why would I invest in one or two military buildings spread out and unbalancing the awful public order/economy mini game, when I might as well wait out a few more turns with tier one slop and mercenaries until I can plop down each kind of barracks and each kind of stat boosting military building in one province? It is just absolutely mind-boggeling the game is designed this way, both for the player and the fact the AI is totally incapable of interacting with it in a meaningful way! 

The politics system is something I can only imagine no player wants to deal with. In theory it offers interesting mechanics and organic fleshed out civil wars, in reality it is just a nerf to expansion and a chore to deal with. Every couple of turns you have to check in on it, click a few buttons out of dozens of confusing options to bring everything back to stasis. 

I could go into the deep reaching effects the removal of general-less armies has, but this review is long enough!
